@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog Iâ€™m not turning this into a witch hunt at all. Iâ€™m challenging opinions and what appears to be an anti-fat bias within you. This is something that happens on public forums all the time and itâ€™s in no way similar or comparable to witch hunts.
@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog challenging perceptions of fat people.

@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog â€œSince I dunno who she is how do you know she was using it negativelyâ€. That sentence seemed to suggest that because you didnâ€™t know who she was Becky couldnâ€™t know her intent. Iâ€™m not trying to pick a fight with you, Iâ€™m advocating for less damaging use of language and
@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog That may be but your words demonstrated that you prioritised the struggles of one group, ie thin people with EDs and dysmorphia over fat people with EDs and dysmorphia.
@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog So because you donâ€™t know who Leah is neither does Becky? Can you only know of the same people?

@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog I never said you hate anyone for their size, but it was hard to ignore that you advocated for thin people with EDs and dysmorphia saying whatever they want but not seeming to care if it hurts fat people with EDs and dysmorphia. It signals that you value one group above the other.

@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog Nobody is saying peope should never use the word fat, if we were we wouldnâ€™t have reclaimed it, but I donâ€™t think itâ€™s unfair for fat people to ask for it to not be used as a synonym for or in the same breath as â€œhideous, ugly, disgusting, awful, lazyâ€ etc.

@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog exclusive and hurtful language, but you seem to not care about fat people facing those same challenges. It may be worth doing some introspection and examining why you feel fat people are less deserving of the courtesy and respect you automatically bestow upon thin people.

@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog Overweight does not necessarily mean unhealthy, and there are many reasons why people are overweight, some of which have little to do with diet and exercise. I also find it really interesting that you brought up eating disorders and body dysmorphia to justify thin people using

@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog There absolutely is. â€œIâ€™m struggling with my confidence todayâ€ â€œI feel so unattractive todayâ€ â€œIâ€™m bloatedâ€ â€œI feel like I need to work on my bodyâ€ are just some of the many ways you can express discontent with your body without throwing fat people under the bus.

@fleur_charms @beckybarnesblog Fat people have eating disorders and body dysmorphia too, and them having to listen to thin people say â€œI feel fatâ€ is incredibly damaging. Just choose different words, itâ€™s not hard.
@annascanlon @ChloeInCurve So true, it seems many people are incredibly intimidated by women who love themselves, and that intimidation increases tenfold if they see a fat woman love herself.

@bellahappyfeet @fatnutritionist Yeah, I never watch those shows anymore. Itâ€™s just so frustrating to start watching a show and you begin to enjoy it and then thereâ€™ll be a few episodes with anti-fat jokes and comments. Itâ€™s in everything, even shows with positive fat characters, like Gilmore Girls.
@fatnutritionist @bellahappyfeet Yeah, I get that completely, I avoid those myself.

@fatnutritionist I think one of the worst things for me is when some thins say â€œwhy shouldnâ€™t we be treated better, we worked hard to look like thisâ€ when so many didnâ€™t work hard at it at all. Thatâ€™s just how they look naturally, regardless of what they eat, and without lifting a finger.

@fatnutritionist @bellahappyfeet Genuine question, how do you avoid fatphobic tv? Like there are some obvious shows to avoid, but fatphobia is, to some extent, present in pretty much every tv show ever and I just donâ€™t understand how thatâ€™s possible but would very much like to know.
@kayleerumsberg Fair enough. I agree that if someone makes a comment about another personâ€™s body, however wrong that is, the right way to deal with it is not by commenting on their body in return.

@kayleerumsberg I donâ€™t think it implies that, she made the tweet to say making comments about peopleâ€™s bodies isnâ€™t ok, so why would she do it back? I think it meant sheâ€™s not letting them get away with it and will tell them the actual reason for the weight loss, ie. â€œI had an organ removedâ€.

@kayleerumsberg What do you mean by making the same comments? Was anyone suggesting on commenting on their body in return? If someone did thatâ€™s not cool, but I donâ€™t see anything wrong with the OPs approach in responding. Itâ€™s just being honest and giving the person a reality check.

@kayleerumsberg Does that not apply to people making unsolicited comments about other peopleâ€™s bodies? Why would I make them feel good about that if it hurts me? Why shouldnâ€™t I calmly tell them itâ€™s unwanted if it keeps them from hurting others in the future?

@KevinGall67 @VivMcGregor made an intentional effort to lose weight is great, but unsolicited body comments or â€œcomplimentsâ€ can have the complete opposite effect. I donâ€™t understand why thatâ€™s so hard for you to grasp.

@KevinGall67 @VivMcGregor You realise youâ€™re making a huge generalisation when you assume everyone wants to be congratulated on weight loss, right? I recognise that compliments like that can be a big boost to some people, thatâ€™s why I stated in a previous comment that complimenting people you know

@KevinGall67 @VivMcGregor I honestly donâ€™t think asking people not to comment on your body & pointing out that it can be very harmful is acting offended or bitching and moaning. I think itâ€™s good to make people aware, and I think youâ€™re the one currently moaning and complainingðŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸
@KevinGall67 @VivMcGregor Sure you can, just donâ€™t comment on other peopleâ€™s bodies unless you know it wonâ€™t cause damage. Itâ€™s really not that hard.
@CherryAnnAustin @KevinGall67 @VivMcGregor Yup, been there myself with bulimia. The compliments completely messed with my head.

@KevinGall67 @VivMcGregor And for some people it can be extremely damaging. If someone brings up that theyâ€™ve been trying to lose weight, feel free to congratulate. But unsolicited comments can be harmful.

@kayleerumsberg @VivMcGregor @punnysamosa If it stops them from making the same assumptions and comments about someone elseâ€™s body, it absolutely is okay. Itâ€™s not their place to comment on other peopleâ€™s bodies, and doing so can be incredibly damaging.
